'''''Cantharellus lateritius''''', commonly known as the '''smooth chanterelle''', is a species of [[edible mushroom|edible]] fungus in the [[Cantharellaceae]] family of [[mushroom]]s. A [[ectomycorrhiza]]l species, it is found in Asia, Africa, and North America. The species has a complex [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] history, and has undergone several name changes since its first [[species description|description]] by American mycologist [[Lewis David de Schweinitz]] in 1822. The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] of the fungus are brightly colored yellow to orange, and usually highly conspicuous against the soil in which they are found. At maturity, the mushroom resembles a filled funnel with the spore-bearing surface along the sloping outer sides. The texture of the fertile undersurface ([[hymenium]]) of the [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] is a distinguishing characteristic of the species: unlike the well-known [[golden chanterelle]], the hymenium of ''C. lateritius'' is much smoother. [[Analytical chemistry|Chemical analysis]] has revealed the presence of several [[carotenoid]] compounds in the fruit bodies.

==Taxonomy==
[[File:Miles Joseph Berkeley00.jpg|thumb|180px|left|[[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berkeley]] is credited with the original authorship of the species.]]

The species was first [[species description|described]] in the scientific literature as ''Thelephora cantharella'' by the American [[Lewis David de Schweinitz]] in 1822, based on specimens collected in [[Ohio]].<ref name=Schweinitz1822/> [[Elias Magnus Fries]] later transferred it to ''[[Craterellus]]'' in his 1838 ''Epicrisis Systematis Mycologici''.<ref name=Fries1838/> In 1856, [[Miles Joseph Berkeley]] and [[Moses Ashley Curtis]] mentioned the fungus in their analysis of Schweinitz's specimens, but changed the [[specific name (botany)|epithet]], calling it ''Craterellus lateritius''.<ref name=Berkeley1856/> The motivation for the name change is unclear; [[Ronald H. Petersen]], in a 1979 publication, suggests that Berkeley "was apparently reluctant to surrender his own name for the organism".<ref name=Petersen1979/> Petersen suggests that Berkeley may have foreseen the necessity to avoid giving the species a [[tautonym]] (a situation where both the generic name and [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] are identical). However, as Petersen indicates, a future publication renders this explanation dubious: in 1873 Berkeley again referred to the species using his chosen name ''Craterellus lateritius'', and indicated a [[Type locality (biology)|type location]] ([[Alabama]]) different than the one mentioned by Schweinitz.<ref name=Berkeley1873/> Petersen considers Berkeley's name to be a ''[[nomen novum]]'' (new name), not a new species, as Berkeley clearly indicated that he thought ''Craterellus lateritius'' was [[synonym (taxonomy)|synonymous]] with Schweinitz's ''Thelephora cantharella''. Normally in these circumstances, Schweinitz's specimen would be considered the [[type (biology)|type]], but Petersen was unable to locate Schweinitz's original specimen, and thus according to the [[International Code of Botanical Nomenclature|rules of botanical nomenclature]], Berkeley's epithet has [[Principle of Priority|precedence]] as it is the earliest published name that has an associated type specimen.<ref name=Petersen1979/>

Another synonym is ''Trombetta lateritia'', used by [[Otto Kuntze]] in his 1891 ''[[Revisio Generum Plantarum]]''.<ref name=Kuntze1891/> American mycologist [[Rolf Singer]] transferred it to the genus ''Cantharellus'' in 1951.<ref name=Singer1951/> The mushroom is commonly known as the "smooth chanterelle".<ref name=Kuo2007/> The [[specific name (botany)|specific name]] ''lateritius'' means "bricklike", and refers to the smooth [[hymenium]].<ref name=Metzler1992/>

==Description==
[[File:Cantharellus lateritius 51632.jpg|thumb|left|The hymenium is initially smooth before developing shallow vein-like ridges in maturity.]]
The [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] of the ''C. lateritius'' [[basidiocarp|fruiting bodies]] typically range between {{convert|2|to|9|cm|in|abbr=on|1}} in diameter, with a flattened to somewhat funnel-shaped top surface and a wavy margin. The cap surface is dry, slightly [[wikt:tomentose|tomentose]] (covered with a layer of fine hairs), and a deep and bright orange-yellow color, with older specimens fading to more yellow in age; the distinctive margins of the cap are a paler yellow,<ref name=Bigelow1978/> and typically curve downward in young specimens.<ref name=Petersen1979/> Fruiting bodies can reach a height of {{convert|12|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Petersen1979/> The hymenophore (the spore-bearing surface) is initially smooth and without wrinkles, but gradually develops channels or ridges, and what appear to be very shallow [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] that are vein-like, and less than 1 mm wide. The color is pale yellow, and is continuous with the surface of the stem. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is rather plump and stout, {{convert|1.5|to|4.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|0.5|to|1.7|cm|1|abbr=on}} thick, more or less cylindrical, tapering downwards towards the base. Internally, the stems are either stuffed (filled with cotton-like [[mycelia]]) or solid. Rarely, fruiting bodies may be clumped together with stems conjoined at the base; in these cases there are usually no more than three fused stems.<ref name=Petersen1979/> The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is solid to partly hollow (sometimes due to insect larvae), with a pale yellow color;<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/> it is {{convert|0.5|to|0.9|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick.<ref name=Miller2006/>

The [[basidiospore|spores]] are smooth, with a roughly [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]] shape, and have typical dimensions of 7–7.5 by 4.5–5 [[micrometre|µm]].<ref>Bigelow (1978) reports more a permissive range of spore sizes: 7.5–9.5 (occasionally up to 12.5) by 4.5–6(6.5) µm</ref> In deposit, such as in a [[spore print]], the spores are light yellow orange,<ref name=Bigelow1978/> while under the microscope they are a very pale yellowish.<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/> The spore bearing cells—the [[basidia]]—are 75–80 by 7–9 µm, 4-5-6-spored,<ref>Bigelow (1978) reports instead 35–72 by 5–7.5 µm, and four spores.</ref> slightly club-shaped, and with a distinctly thickened wall at the base. [[Clamp connection]]s (short branches connecting one cell to the previous cell to allow passage of the products of [[nucleus (cell)|nuclear]] division) are present in the [[hypha]]e of all parts of the fruiting body.<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/>

===Similar species===
{{multiple image
| footer = Potential lookalikes include the poisonous ''[[Omphalotus olearius]]'' (left), and the exceptional edible ''[[Cantharellus cibarius]]'' (right).
| width = 180
| image1 = Omphalotus olearius2.JPG
| image2 = Chanterelle.jpg
}}
''Cantharellus lateritius'' is pinker than the golden chanterelle (''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarius]]''),<ref name="Mui1998"/> and has thicker flesh in addition to the smoother hymenial surface.<ref name=Roody2003/> ''[[Cantharellus odoratus|C. odoratus]]'' is also similar in appearance, and is distinguished by a thinner [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] and a hollow stem.<ref name=Bigelow1978/> The [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] "Jack O'Lantern" mushroom, ''[[Omphalotus olearius]]'', is roughly similar in stature and color, but can be differentiated from ''C. lateritius'' by its true gills with sharply defined edges, and growth on decaying wood (although the wood may be buried in the soil), usually in large overlapping clusters.<ref name=Bessette1992/>

One author considers ''Cantharellus lateritius'' to likely represent a [[species complex]], including "all the chanterelles with a completely smooth hymenophore, sweet smell, and clamped hyphae."<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/>

===Edibility===
Like all species in the genus ''Cantharellus'', ''C. lateritius'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]], and considered choice by some.<ref name=Roody2003/><ref name=McKnight1987/> The odor resembles apricots, and the taste is mild,<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/> or "moderately to faintly acrid".<ref name=Petersen1979/> In the opinion of McFarland and Mueller, authors of a field guide to edible fungi of [[Illinois]], compared to the well-known ''C. cibarius'', ''C. lateritius'' is "in general ... somewhat disappointing when compared with their delicious relatives".<ref name=Mueller2009/>

==Distribution and habitat==
[[File:Cantharellus lateritius 49073.jpg|thumb|right|Not yet fully mature specimens collected from [[Strouds Run State Park]], Ohio]]
''Cantharellus lateritius'' is distributed in North America, Africa, Malaysia,<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/> and the [[Himalayas]] (specifically, the [[Almora]] hills in [[Uttar Pradesh]]).<ref name=Dhancholia1991/> In the United States, its range extends northward to [[Michigan]] and [[New England]].<ref name=Petersen1979/>

Typically found growing solitary, in groups or in clusters under [[hardwood]] trees, the fungus produces fruit bodies in the summer and autumn.<ref name=Miller2006/> In the [[New England]] area of the United States, mycologist Howard Bigelow has noted it to grow on road shoulders in grass near [[oak]]s;<ref name=Bigelow1978/> it also has a predilection for growing on sloping creek banks.<ref name=Metzler1992/> In Malaysia, it is found growing on the soil in forests, mostly under species of ''[[Shorea]]'' ([[rainforest]] trees in the family [[Dipterocarpaceae]]).<ref name="Eyssartier2009"/> ''C. lateritius'' has been reported from the [[Western Ghats]], [[Kerala]], India, forming [[ectomycorrhiza]]l association with [[endemism|endemic]] tree species like ''[[Vateria indica]]'', ''[[Hopea parviflora]]'', ''[[Diospyros malabarica]]'', ''[[Myristica malabarica]]'' in semi-evergreen to evergreen forests.<ref name=Mohanan2011/>

==Bioactive compounds==

In a 1998 study, the [[carotenoid]] composition of this species was compared to several other ''[[Cantharellus]]'' species, including ''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarus]]'', ''C. cibarius'' var. ''amythysteus'', and ''[[Cantharellus tabernensis|C. tabernensis]]''. The carotenoid content between species was "virtually identical", comprising [[gamma-carotene|γ-carotene]], [[alpha-carotene|α-carotene]], and [[beta-carotene|β-carotene]]. The only significant difference was that ''C. lateritius'' contained a significant quantity of an unidentified carotene that was thought to be a [[chemical decomposition|breakdown product]] of β-carotene.<ref name="Mui1998"/>
